title: Roman Emperors Quiz
description: Can you recall the emperors who ruled the mighty Roman Empire?

questions.question: Which emperor is famous for reportedly fiddling while Rome burned in 64 AD?
questions.explanation: While the story is likely a myth (the fiddle hadn't been invented yet), Emperor Nero is traditionally associated with the Great Fire of Rome in 64 AD.

questions.question: Which emperor legalized Christianity with the Edict of Milan in 313 AD?
questions.explanation: Emperor Constantine I issued the Edict of Milan in 313 AD, granting religious tolerance throughout the empire and ending the persecution of Christians.

questions.question: Which emperor built Hadrian's Wall in northern England?
questions.explanation: Emperor Hadrian ordered the construction of the wall in 122 AD to mark the northern boundary of the Roman Empire in Britain.

questions.question: Which emperor was known as a mad tyrant who allegedly made his horse a consul?
questions.explanation: Emperor Caligula (Gaius Caesar) was known for his cruelty and extravagance. The story about his horse Incitatus being made consul is likely exaggerated.

questions.question: Under which emperor did the Roman Empire reach its greatest territorial extent?
questions.explanation: Emperor Trajan expanded the Roman Empire to its greatest extent by 117 AD, including conquests in Dacia (modern Romania) and Mesopotamia.

questions.question: Which emperor split the Roman Empire into Eastern and Western halves for easier governance?
questions.explanation: Emperor Diocletian established the Tetrarchy in 293 AD, dividing the empire into Eastern and Western administrative units.

questions.question: Which emperor ordered the construction of the Colosseum?
questions.explanation: Emperor Vespasian began construction of the Colosseum around 70 AD. It was completed under his son Titus in 80 AD.

questions.question: Which emperor was the last to rule over a united Roman Empire?
questions.explanation: Theodosius I was the last emperor to rule over both the Eastern and Western Roman Empire. After his death in 395 AD, the empire was permanently divided.

questions.question: Which emperor established the Pax Romana, a long period of relative peace?
questions.explanation: Augustus (Octavian) established the Pax Romana beginning in 27 BC, a roughly 200-year period of relative peace and stability across the Roman Empire.

questions.question: Which emperor was a gladiator who fought in the arena and was eventually assassinated?
questions.explanation: Emperor Commodus was obsessed with gladiatorial combat and fought in the arena himself. He was assassinated by strangling in 192 AD.

questions.question: Which philosopher-emperor wrote 'Meditations' and was the last of the Five Good Emperors?
questions.explanation: Marcus Aurelius (161-180 AD) was the last of the Five Good Emperors and wrote his famous Stoic philosophical work 'Meditations.'

questions.question: Which emperor was assassinated on the Ides of March (March 15, 44 BC)?
questions.explanation: Julius Caesar was assassinated by a group of senators on March 15, 44 BC. While technically a dictator rather than emperor, his death led to the empire.

questions.question: Which emperor moved the capital of the Roman Empire to Constantinople?
questions.explanation: Constantine I founded Constantinople (modern Istanbul) in 330 AD as the new capital of the Roman Empire, on the site of ancient Byzantium.

questions.question: Which was the last Western Roman Emperor, deposed in 476 AD?
questions.explanation: Romulus Augustulus was deposed by the Germanic chieftain Odoacer in 476 AD, traditionally marking the fall of the Western Roman Empire.

questions.question: Which emperor adopted Trajan as his successor, starting a tradition of adoptive succession?
questions.explanation: Emperor Nerva adopted Trajan as his heir in 97 AD, beginning the era of the Five Good Emperors and the practice of choosing the most capable successor.
